Jon Skeet wrote:

> Is anything planned in JUnit4 to mirror the Category attribute in NUnit?
<snip />
> Personally, I think this would be great functionality to have in the
> core of JUnit4.
> 
> So, why am I wrong? :)

You're not wrong, but I do something differently, and prefer it.

Tests sometimes naturally divide themselves along the axis of "how often 
we run them". Performance tests don't run as often as object tests, 
because the former are slower and can get in the way of the latter. When 
this happens, I split the source tree in two, putting the performance 
tests in their own source tree, apart from the object tests. I've done 
this so often that I end up with this default structure for Java projects:

production/
     source/
     classes/
test/
     source/
     classes/
endtoend/
     source/
     classes/
fixture/
     source/
     classes/
performance/
     source/
     classes/
...and so on. Each source tree gets it own source and classes directories.

Separate source trees have many benefits:
  * Eclipse can run all the tests in one source tree easily
  * Different items are built to different locations, making it easier 
to avoid production code depending on test code
  * Easy to ship the production code without the tests, since that's 
still the norm

I used to use separate projects, but that creates annoying class path 
problems, so I settled on separate source trees. My Ant tasks mirror 
what Eclipse does, building separate source trees to separate build 
locations.

The bottom line: if the tests are really /that/ different, then we 
should emphasize the difference by placing the tests in different 
locations, rather that merely annotating them.
